fields.title: Metformin, the big new "anti-aging" drug, explained
fields.description:
﻿I stumbled into the weirdest thing recently, 
and it all starts with this little pill... “Researchers discover some very exciting new 
benefits of a drug already on the market…” “Metformin” “metformin” “metformin” “The first anti-aging drug..." "Possible anti-aging drug..." "Can you spell it? M-E-T...
fields.text:
﻿I stumbled into the weirdest thing recently, 
and it all starts with this little pill... “Researchers discover some very exciting new 
benefits of a drug already on the market…” “Metformin” “metformin” “metformin” “The first anti-aging drug..." "Possible anti-aging drug..." "Can you spell it? M-E-T... "Could be revolutionary!" "Is it really the fountain of youth?
Are we onto something here?" This isn't some sketchy supplement. It’s a real drug! It’s been used effectively 
by people with diabetes for decades to control their blood sugar. And it's cheap! It's really cheap. It's pennies per pill. It’s all in the news now because it's getting
popular with another group of people with a lot of money, for a different purpose. So… to try to live longer, billionaires 
are taking a pill that costs pennies. Does it... work?? DR. NIR BARZILAI: This is important... Anti-aging generally has a bad name.
In anti-aging there are lots of charlatans. “What are you selling, mister? Snake oil?” “I tell you Mother, we’re cheating 
all the people, don’t you see?”  BARZILAI: "You'll take this 
and you live forever."And if they die,   nobody sues them, right? So those are our enemy. That’s Dr. Nir Barzilai.
He’s the person you call if you have serious questions about aging. And he answered my first one right away... We're not talking about a... “fountain of youth”  "The fountain of youth" “The fountain of youth!” “You found no fountain of youth here!” BARZILAI: The thing that is not happening is taking an old person and making young, okay? Sorry. What researchers are actually trying to do is figure out if there's any way we can
delay the effects of aging. And I don’t mean wrinkles and gray hair. I mean about the chance you die. As you age, the chance you die goes up. Specifically, the chance you die from 
these very common diseases goes up. Why does the chance of dying from cancer, 
heart disease, Alzheimer's go up with age? BARZILAI: We're thinking wrong about 
it. It's the biology of aging that   drives the disease. And if you stop this 
biology of aging, you stop this disease. What he told me, and this took me a minute to wrap 
my head around, is that: Our bodies accumulate   damage as time goes on. The diseases most of 
us die from spring from that damage - often in   ways we don’t totally understand. But if you could delay the damage somehow,   you could also delay the diseases, right? And 
make it more likely you survive for longer. And in 2014, Dr. Barzilai happened on the 
results of a very interesting study…
  BARZILAI: This is a study from the UK where 
they took 180,000 people approximately… They looked at three groups of people: 
People with diabetes taking metformin,   people with diabetes taking other drugs 
not metformin, and people without diabetes   who weren’t taking any diabetes drugs. The people with diabetes who weren't
taking metformin had double the mortality - the number of 
deaths - than the people without diabetes.
  BARZILAI: But this is really what was cool: People 
on metformin that were diabetics, were more obese,   they were more sick to begin with, had less 
mortality than people without diabetes. The fact that people with 
diabetes who were taking metformin   died less than people
WITHOUT diabetes is HUGE. But if you're applying that to anti-aging,
there are some really big caveats: First: These are correlations.
This is a retrospective study. They’re looking back at what happened, they weren't able to test whether metformin
CAUSED it to happen. And second, the only people taking metformin
in this study were people with diabetes. It’s not clear whether that whole
“dying less” thing   applies to people without diabetes. And at this point,
you might be wondering “how does it even work?” Well, we know a lot about 
how metformin works in people with diabetes:  When you eat or drink, your blood transports 
sugars to your cells to use as fuel.   In people with diabetes, these blood sugar levels 
can get too high and metformin helps control that.   We have research on this going back decades to 
before metformin was first approved. We know a lot less about how it may or may not 
work in people without diabetes for anti-aging.   One reason for that is, these days, it’s 
already a cheap generic drug, which means   there’s not as much incentive for pharmaceutical 
companies to do expensive new research. Other studies show metformin does seem 
to have anti-aging effects in healthy   mice and worms. Which is interesting… But to know for sure whether
metformin can actually delay aging in most people,
we need more research. That’s what Dr. Barzilai is trying to do. "Dr. Barzilai is about to launch
a new nationwide study!" "A proper randomized trial where
they give half the people metformin and half the people a placebo drug..." "So you're going to be hearing
a lot more about this in the future!" BARZILAI: This is really the challenge 
that I'm leading now. This is the TAME study.   TAME stands for Targeting Aging with Metformin. 
And the reason I’m doing that is not to repeat   the studies that I told you! It’s to really 
plan a study for the FDA to repurpose a drug   that we believe targets aging.  It’s hard to overstate how incredible  this would be if it works.  They’re trying to figure out if   aging is treatable.  if something can push back
the accumulation of damage, and push back the diseases
that kill the most of us.  And if that “something” isn’t some
crazy million-dollar thing   but a drug that is already on the market and 
already affordable for many, many people. I get surprisingly emotional 
thinking about this topic. "That!" "That! Is a camera!" Really, I... genuinely can’t think of anything that I would want 
more than more time with the people I love. In the meantime, whether or not you wanna 
take metformin or I do boils down to our   assessment of 3 different factors: The first is, what you think of
the existing studies  (not the TAME trial, because 
it probably won’t be done for a while) The second is how urgent aging actually feels 
to you. That’s a very personal choice. The third is how you weigh your perceived 
benefits against the side effects… BARZILAI: There's very common side effects in 
the first week of use. You feel early satiety,   you're not hungry. You might have kind of 
upset stomach. You might have diarrhea. It also impacts how your body 
responds to exercise. BARZILAI: When you exercise with or without 
metformin, your muscle will have the same   increased capacity, but the 
muscle wouldn't be as big. Ok. Would I have diarrhea for a 
week and be less good at exercise   if I could live 5 years longer?
Yes. Absolutely. Would I opt in for that if I weren’t
pretty sure it would work?  No, probably not. So the people in the news right now
who are taking metformin for anti-aging, without 
diabetes, are making a specific calculation:   “We don’t want to wait for more studies, 
we’re happy with the studies we have.   We don’t mind these side effects too much, and aging 
feels pretty urgent. We’re getting older.” You know, I’ve been struggling a little bit 
as a journalist working on this piece. Because on the one hand, I really want to
present information that experts tell me is important and valuable for the future. And on the other hand, I really don’t 
want anyone to go take a medication   because they watched a YouTube video! I personally don’t take metformin, that’s how my calculation came out.
I want to wait for more studies. But metformin isn’t the only option being studied. Researchers are looking at more 
and more drugs for anti-aging effects. If we figure out that any option meaningfully
delays the effects of aging in most people that is too huge to ignore or scoff at. 18 million people die of
heart disease every year. 10 million people die of cancer. 55 million people have 
Alzheimers or other dementias. Some of those people are in my family, NONNA: "It's a perfect picture of him..." are my loved ones. Some, I imagine, are yours. And I can’t help but imagine what I would do with more time.

fields.title: Victor Wembanyama Is Something That We Cannot Comprehend | J. Kyle Mann | The Ringer
fields.description: I've always been a big fan of Arrivals in basketball.
fields.text: I've always been a big fan of Arrivals in basketball. Times when the stage has been set for a potential superstar to elevate their game, to grab a moment by the lapels and introduce themselves to the world. You know, the old Lupe fiasco, cliche. If you are who you say you are, a superstar, have no fear. That's what it felt like to be in Las Vegas in early October when the French Phenom, Victor Winman-Yama, took the stage for the first time in front of an American audience and, without rages physical tools, and a mind-meltingly skillful performance, addressed the growing hype around him. All that chatter that you've heard about a French teenager who supposedly implausible tall and phenomenally skilled? Doctor. A few years ago, I randomly saw Jesse Eisenberg at a local pinball bar, at 5'7 with a slight build, I thought, oh, okay. Laying eyes on Victor for the first time, in person, and at eye level, was on the other end of the in-person first impression spectrum. I felt like Alan Grant, seeing a rocky resource for the first time. And then to see him so cool, he confidently rides to the occasion against the G League Ignite with a highlight-heavy display of improbable blocks, skillful finishes around the rim, and a cascade of jumpers from nearly everywhere. I came away feeling like I'd just had a spiritual experience. Why died in reeling? I felt like I'd seen the future of basketball. Front offices around the NBA likely felt the same way. That's because the man they call Wimpy is the latest entry in a truly rare bloodline of player. So few times has something like this happened in the history of basketball. Kareem in 1969, a keen in 1984, Shaq in 1992, Tim Duncan in 1997, LeBron and O3. These were prospects that were so special, so obviously context and culture shifting, and so clearly on a path to transcendent superstardom that it's difficult to know just how far teams will be willing to go, or how much they'll be willing to sabotage their seasons in order to have a chance to land his services. There'll be plenty of time to fully evaluate Victor Winmanyama as we get closer to the draft, but before we do, I think that we should set out to answer some basic questions. Who is this guy? And what exactly is it about him that has fans and executives alike droning on and on? Is any of this real, or is he simply a novelty who had a big game at the right time? Victor Winmanyama was born on January 4th, 2004 and hails from La Shanae, France, a suburb just west of Paris. Although he just hit the mainstream vick is not a recent revelation, his pro career started with Nuttera 92 in 2019 when he was only 15 years old. One year before a clip of him playing two on two with fellow Frenchman Rudy Goberr went viral and caused the basketball world to look at their phones like Jimmy Dolan in the air up there. From Nuttera 92 he joined as Vell Villaban, a Euro League team owned by another legendary friend Cooper and Tony Parker, and in the fall of 2022 he decided to play for Metropolitan's 92. Victor's physical measurements are visibly extraterrestrial, but the details are hazy. In early September it was tweeted that Vic had measured 7 foot 4 in bare feet with an 8 foot wingspan, both absolutely shocking numbers. Vic however recently clarified that he has measured at 7 foot 3 in bare feet. You need only your eyes to understand that Wimbin Yama is fantastically long and taller than nearly anyone currently in the NBA. In every game that he is a part of, there's a freeze frame that almost feels like it's in the uncanny valley. He's thin, but with promising broad shoulders and a gate that is very much uncommon for such a frame. Vic is guarded about his influences as a player, but his ambitions are strong. If any person could say this and have it not be comedy, if anyone were capable of truly becoming something that we cannot comprehend, it's Victor Linman Yama. Among active players the comparisons are difficult. There are currently 5 players in the NBA who stay in 7 foot 2 or taller. The beloved Boba Marjana-Bitch, Bulbol, Christap's for Zingas, Luke Cornet, and Moses Brown. Only Boba who is much slower, stiffer, and far less flexible is comparably as tall and long. For Zingas and Cornet, also significantly inferior athletes are similar as shooters and only Bulb and Brown are similar in agility. None of them wrap the entire package into one like Wimbin Yama and that's not to mention that his feel for the game and competitiveness are a level above any of those players. This rarity forces us to rummage across eras. Only a handful of players in history have had a remotely similar convergence of gifts, and because Vic is growing up impacted by a world where the ball handling and shooting revolutions have already taken place, the skill comparisons are harder to make. Yao Ming, Arvita Sabonis, and Rick Smith's. Rick Smith's was really good and doesn't get enough credit. These were all giant human beings with polished ball skills, all things considered, but again, none of them were as mobile or defensively impactful as Wimbin Yama projects to beat. Many have agreed that watching Vic gracefully move among his peers stirs up visions of cream-abdule debars early days of power memorial in New York City. But even Ralph Sampson, a common comp who was listed at 7'4, was likely not as long or as tall. Some have expressed skepticism about Sampson's true size. Are you bigger than Sampson? Yeah, yeah. He's, I'd say, in the name of the 7'1, Rich Kelly's almost as tall as he is. Personally, I think a huge separating trait for Victor is his touch. To have arms as wide as a leer jet and hands the size of booky boards, he exhibits terrific touch when shooting and even passing the ball. Because of his size and lean frame, much of Vic's offensive life is facing up to the basket at this point. He demonstrated on a few occasions that he can attack the clothes out and finish with some creativity, and he's very quick and aggressive on the offensive glass. But the most impressive recent development in his game has been the ease with which he's getting to his jump shot. If he was simply catching and shooting at that size, great, his release point is incredibly high. But the flashes of versatility have been remarkable. Even more encouraging when we hear that he's been working with Holger Geshwinder, Dirk Novetzky's lifelong shooting coach, and by extension the man whose teachings had a profound influence on Kevin Durant. A wise move for someone who seems to prefer ripped through jumpers in the mid-range and off the bounce bumps that lead to fade away. That said, this is something to keep an eye on. Vic is still streaky and inconsistent as a shooter which makes his spectacular outburst in Las Vegas where he went 9 for 18 from 3, a little trickier to contextualize. The circumstances surrounding the shots are certainly a factor, but in the two biggest sustained shooting samples of his young career, he's returned varying results. 18 games during the 2020-21 season when he shot a satisfying 36.4% in 20 games during the 2021-22 season when he shot a less-than-stellar 26%. Approaching the rim, Wimpy has an absurd catch radius as a vertical spacer, as you to imagine. His rare flexibility is visible when he takes contact around the rim and is able to not only take a bump but improvise in the air, extend and still finish with touch. To be clear, this is not normal for a player who is 7'4", because of his slight abilities most frequently popping out of ball screens looking for a jumper or trying to surprise the defense by slipping to the basket. He is also capable of making quick passing reads, I love this touch pass to a teammate under the rim, but it wouldn't categorize him as a manipulative pass or particularly creative. If that weren't enough, optimistic projections are that win-man-yama could become one of the more unique defensive anchors that we have ever seen. It could be the result of playing soccer as a goalie growing up, but in sheer size and feel for the game, he is perpetually disruptive. In ball screen coverages, he's quick and mobile enough and his lower body to switch on the smaller players in open space in more than hold his own, and he's long enough to drop or softly show and deter both pull up shooters and potential lob threats. He can test and erase his shots well with either hand, sometimes within the same play. Watch him cause two would be shooters in one sequence to think otherwise and then simply wall up to eradicate this challenge or the rim. Look, we're only scratching the surface, but here's the bottom line. When you add the filters of being 7'4' taller with a wingspan of at least 7'10, exceptional lateral agility and athletic elasticity, touch and creativity as a shooter and a self-creation score, high level impact as a defensive anchor that could reach defensive player of the year status, not to mention the poise and competitive instincts that he shows on both sides of the ball. Once you've added all of those filters, you've filtered out more or less every basketball player who's ever lived. Now does this mean that Vik will certainly become the best player who ever lived? No, does it even mean that he'll continue to get better? No, does it mean that he will avoid injuries that plague the special big guys that precede him? Again, no, it does not. The word prospect is defined as an apparent probability of success. For Victor Winmanyama with the unshakable confidence that he's shown off the court and the utter dominance that he's enjoyed on it, that probability of success is very much apparent. To quote one of my favorite bands, it's real. That's what we're all so excited about and that's what we're all hoping that we'll get to see. Let me know if you agree.

8 foot wingspan, both absolutely shocking numbers.
Vic however recently clarified that he has measured at 7 foot 3 in bare feet.
You need only your eyes to understand that Wimbin Yama is fantastically long and taller
than nearly anyone currently in the NBA.
In every game that he is a part of, there's a freeze frame that almost feels like it's
in the uncanny valley.
He's thin, but with promising broad shoulders and a gate that is very much uncommon for
such a frame.
Vic is guarded about his influences as a player, but his ambitions are strong.
If any person could say this and have it not be comedy, if anyone were capable of
truly becoming something that we cannot comprehend, it's Victor Linman Yama.
Among active players the comparisons are difficult.
There are currently 5 players in the NBA who stay in 7 foot 2 or taller.
The beloved Boba Marjana-Bitch, Bulbol, Christap's for Zingas, Luke Cornet, and Moses Brown.
Only Boba who is much slower, stiffer, and far less flexible is comparably as tall and
long.
For Zingas and Cornet, also significantly inferior athletes are similar as shooters and only
Bulb and Brown are similar in agility.
None of them wrap the entire package into one like Wimbin Yama and that's not to mention
that his feel for the game and competitiveness are a level above any of those players.
This rarity forces us to rummage across eras.
Only a handful of players in history have had a remotely similar convergence of gifts,
and because Vic is growing up impacted by a world where the ball handling and shooting
revolutions have already taken place, the skill comparisons are harder to make.
Yao Ming, Arvita Sabonis, and Rick Smith's.
Rick Smith's was really good and doesn't get enough credit.
These were all giant human beings with polished ball skills, all things considered, but
again, none of them were as mobile or defensively impactful as Wimbin Yama projects to
beat.
Many have agreed that watching Vic gracefully move among his peers stirs up visions of
cream-abdule debars early days of power memorial in New York City.
But even Ralph Sampson, a common comp who was listed at 7'4, was likely not as long
or as tall.
Some have expressed skepticism about Sampson's true size.
Are you bigger than Sampson?
Yeah, yeah.
He's, I'd say, in the name of the 7'1, Rich Kelly's almost as tall as he is.
Personally, I think a huge separating trait for Victor is his touch.
To have arms as wide as a leer jet and hands the size of booky boards, he exhibits terrific
touch when shooting and even passing the ball.
Because of his size and lean frame, much of Vic's offensive life is facing up to the basket
at this point.
He demonstrated on a few occasions that he can attack the clothes out and finish with some
creativity, and he's very quick and aggressive on the offensive glass.
But the most impressive recent development in his game has been the ease with which he's
getting to his jump shot.
If he was simply catching and shooting at that size, great, his release point is incredibly
high.
But the flashes of versatility have been remarkable.
Even more encouraging when we hear that he's been working with Holger Geshwinder,
Dirk Novetzky's lifelong shooting coach, and by extension the man whose teachings had
a profound influence on Kevin Durant.
A wise move for someone who seems to prefer ripped through jumpers in the mid-range and
off the bounce bumps that lead to fade away.
That said, this is something to keep an eye on.
Vic is still streaky and inconsistent as a shooter which makes his spectacular outburst
in Las Vegas where he went 9 for 18 from 3, a little trickier to contextualize.
The circumstances surrounding the shots are certainly a factor, but in the two biggest
sustained shooting samples of his young career, he's returned varying results.
18 games during the 2020-21 season when he shot a satisfying 36.4% in 20 games during the
2021-22 season when he shot a less-than-stellar 26%.
Approaching the rim, Wimpy has an absurd catch radius as a vertical spacer, as you
to imagine.
His rare flexibility is visible when he takes contact around the rim and is able to not
only take a bump but improvise in the air, extend and still finish with touch.
To be clear, this is not normal for a player who is 7'4", because of his slight
abilities most frequently popping out of ball screens looking for a jumper or trying
to surprise the defense by slipping to the basket.
He is also capable of making quick passing reads, I love this touch pass to a teammate
under the rim, but it wouldn't categorize him as a manipulative pass or particularly creative.
If that weren't enough, optimistic projections are that win-man-yama could become one of the
more unique defensive anchors that we have ever seen.
It could be the result of playing soccer as a goalie growing up, but in sheer size
and feel for the game, he is perpetually disruptive.
In ball screen coverages, he's quick and mobile enough and his lower body to switch on
the smaller players in open space in more than hold his own, and he's long enough to
drop or softly show and deter both pull up shooters and potential lob threats.
He can test and erase his shots well with either hand, sometimes within the same play.
Watch him cause two would be shooters in one sequence to think otherwise and then simply
wall up to eradicate this challenge or the rim.
Look, we're only scratching the surface, but here's the bottom line.
When you add the filters of being 7'4' taller with a wingspan of at least 7'10, exceptional
lateral agility and athletic elasticity, touch and creativity as a shooter and a self-creation
score, high level impact as a defensive anchor that could reach defensive player of the
year status, not to mention the poise and competitive instincts that he shows on both sides
of the ball.
Once you've added all of those filters, you've filtered out more or less every basketball
player who's ever lived.
Now does this mean that Vik will certainly become the best player who ever lived?
No, does it even mean that he'll continue to get better?
No, does it mean that he will avoid injuries that plague the special big guys that
precede him?
Again, no, it does not.
The word prospect is defined as an apparent probability of success.
For Victor Winmanyama with the unshakable confidence that he's shown off the court and the
utter dominance that he's enjoyed on it, that probability of success is very much apparent.
To quote one of my favorite bands, it's real.
That's what we're all so excited about and that's what we're all hoping that we'll get
to see.
Let me know if you agree.

find an oversized button-up like this in pretty much any thrift store to make it look less risky business and more of an outfit i'm cinching in the waist with a statement belt and adding some black accessories to tie everything together to wear it as a blouse without looking too corporate i'm unbuttoning the shirt and pushing it back on my shoulders to create this wide almost off the shoulder neckline and cuffing the sleeves now admittedly i kind of look like a schoolteacher but at least i look like the cool school teacher that you have a crush on to style an oversized men's jacket cough the sleeves and wear it slightly off the shoulder this works particularly well with a soft less structured fabric so it drapes off your body rather than looking like too chunky and weird around the shoulders if you don't have any boys in your life to steal from try repurposing your grandma's silk scarf or more accurately one from a stranger's grandma that i got from a goodwill outlet oh god i'm wearing dead people clothing aren't i anyways to turn this into a top wrap it around your boobs twist it in the back and secure a knot in the front this is surprisingly secure i honestly could do some good bouncing in this top but i'm not gonna give that one to our resonant channel pervs but if you need to you can tuck the edges of the scarf into your strapless bra for some added security swapping out the sandals for boots here's a warmer version that doesn't let the top shine as much but it's still a good option for those days when all your t-shirts are dirty but you still have three pairs of underwear left so you refuse to do the laundry out of pride not speaking from personal experience or anything i know what you're thinking ashley i'm not a [ __ ] power ranger how am i supposed to casually have a suit of entirely one color i will say monochrome looks are easier to pull together than you might expect and instantly make you look like you put an honestly intimidating amount of effort into your outfit obviously the easiest way is to go for an all-white or all-black outfit but even if you are putting together a colorful outfit really the shades don't have to match exactly like here i have three very different shades of tan but it still overall reads as monochrome and honestly i think it's a bit better if the shades are different so it adds some dimension to your outfit here are some other tips for putting together monochrome outfits try mixing up the textures like here i have both leather and denim add some accessories to add detail and don't be afraid to add a little pop of a contrasting color like the text on this t-shirt on the opposite end of the spectrum there has never been a better time to get wild with some pattern mixing does this look cool or do i look like i'm a christmas elf addicted to hot topic i don't know but there's bound to be some niche on instagram who's into that personally though i do think it works especially because the black in the leopard print and the floral print and the black of my jeans and shoes ties the whole outfit together i think that's the key with pattern mixing you really want to have at least one common color between all of your prints denim on denim used to make me want to [ __ ] tear my eyeballs out but somewhere in the past year i have given in to the dark wash side but um if you don't want an outfit that screams canadian tuxedo and try mixing a light and dark wash to break out the look alternatively here is an outfit with similar washes but i think it works because the sherpa lining on my jacket and my exposed legoronies prevent me from looking too stuffy and all that denim i really didn't know what to call this section but basically here are some interesting outfit combinations to try most people reserve thigh high boots for short skirts and if you're ariana grande oversized hoodies but you can make them look a lot less dangerous woman with a midi skirt since you can't see the end of the boots i think it looks quite chic and ladylike this combination has been my go-to lately which is juxtaposing a girly mini dress with chunky platform shoes or boots with some type of hardware on them i just think it looks really cool and casual and it's such a foolproof combination next up you could try a menswear inspired look with an oversized blazer a turtleneck and some loafers sometimes i feel like it's intimidating to put that many menswear inspired pieces together but as long as you have well-fitting jeans and an exposed ankle you won't get too lost in fabric and i think it looks very oxford chic and finally try layering a chunky sweater over a skirt and leaving it untucked for a drop waist silhouette i chronically tuck in my shirts and sweaters so this look is kind of new for me but i think it's quite cute and let me tell you it is fantastic for hiding a food baby too just make sure to wear shoes with a little bit of height to balance out the chunkier silhouette you guys know i am no stranger to showing off some scandalous shoulders and ambiguous upper thigh ass territory but some dresses are a little bit too sexual even for me so here's how you turn a nighttime lingerie look into a daytime outfit first i'm layering a t-shirt underneath to cover up the old bobberonies and creating a cute layered look and then i'm tucking my dress into some loose military inspired pants for a masculine meets feminine look for this next look i'm layering an oversized blazer on top to balance out how short and tight the skirt is popping on some flat loafers i really didn't want anything with a heel because i already have so much leg out and voila now i have a sexy hermione halloween costume i have also been loving the corset bodice trend lately i layered a turtleneck under this sheer bodysuit for some extra coverage and paired it with a checkered skirt for some subtle pattern mixing and here is an edgier option with that same bodice i don't know i just love the layered look and i think corsets are a great way to add a pop of color and texture to an otherwise pretty plain outfit [Music] i don't know if this is like too simple to put in this video but another tip is to play around with the necklines on tops that you already have so if you have a wide neck top like this try moving the sleeves off the shoulder for a more feminine dainty off-the-shoulder look and if you live through 2016 you probably have a top that looks something like this if you've worn the off-the-shoulder look to death you can shimmy up the sleeve nubbins to create this kind of scoop neck t-shirt with an exposed back and this is the final tip of this video thank god because i need a [ __ ] glass of water after narrating all of this if you have a plain dress that you've worn the heck out of try changing it up with some statement belts or scarves this is like a random gingham piece of fabric that came with a shirt that i thrifted or you could even use a scrap of fabric from a craft store for this i'm just tying it around my waist as one does here is a little no-sew hack for you guys if your dress is a bit long tuck in some of the extra fabric around your waist and if your sash is large enough it should hide any wrinkles quite well and there we go now my basic dress is picnic [ __ ] approved here's another option with that dead grandma scarf from earlier i'm leaving it quite thick to create a kind of pseudo corset look and pairing it with these suede boots and now i'm ready to uh woo some boys at the county fair you guys have seen this belt before but it's literally the best 15 i've ever spent it completely changes up a dress and i love the juxtaposition between this beachy white dress and some black hardware and those are all 50 outfits this is my first video that i'm filming in my new apartment and goddamn i'm so excited to have enough space to film these outfit videos without like rearranging my whole bedroom so look forward to many more fashion videos to come otherwise thank you so much for watching and i will see you guys next week hi hey guys it's ashley here to talk why am i waiting for the camera for that hey guys

fields.title: Joe Rogan & Lex Fridman: Lionel Messi Is The GOAT Over Cristiano Ronaldo
fields.description: You're a part of mixed martial arts.
fields.text: You're a part of mixed martial arts. It's people that move in interesting ways. Move well in interesting ways. I was thinking, you know who Lionel Messi is being sure? So the soccer player, he's my favorite. Talking about things that divide the populace with the vaccines is probably Messi versus Christiano Ronaldo, who's the greatest player of all time, or currently playing that divides people too. But what is the division? They're just both incredible. But what is it like who's better LeBron or Michael Jordan? Is it like that kind of thing? People get very passionate about that. They extremely passionate. Who do you think is better? Messi by far. How can you? How can you? I'm far by far. So what I was so sometimes, well, so it has to do with movement. So it has to do with where you put priorities. So the other people in the running for greatest ever, I don't even think we're not all those in the top five, but is Maradona, Pellet. So more shots fired moment right here? Did you shot was? Was that not fired? That was, yeah. I'm not allowed to loop when it comes to soccer, but I think you just made something. I think the Brazilian resistance. Yeah, I think the Brazilian resistance or no, those better than Christiano. But so Christiano is much better looking. He's much harder working. He's an incredible soccer player. One of the greatest ever, just not in the top five for me. Messi moves like nothing I have ever seen. And this is like a lot of people agree that there's moments of genius unlike anybody else. This everybody agrees on. And the question is, how much do you value moments of genius in terms of movement? Just like how many things you're able to create, they're like, what the fuck did I just want? Right. That I value that above all else. Now one of the reasons why until like a month ago, people still said Messi might not be the greatest ever is because he's never taken his national team, Argentina, to a major, like a World Cup win, or the Copo America, or like the major international win. He's always, he's taken him to the final a bunch of times, but never won. And so that has to, that's like LeBron questions. How many times if ever did you take your team, especially when the team is not great, did you make them step up to win the championship? Right. And until this, so he won the South American championship, which is a huge championship for the first time with Argentina last month, which solidified them is the greatest. Anyway, I'm making some enemies now. But the main point is the movement, I think I want to agree, he is in, like when you watch him, it's art. And I was thinking in the same way, who is that? Like if you didn't see the face or the uniform, if you just saw the silhouette, you could tell it's Messi. And I was thinking who is that for MMA? Mighty Mouse. Mighty Mouse is the greatest I've ever seen. So I was thinking Anderson Silva. Nah, well Anderson Silva was fantastic, and it's prime, no doubt about it. But Mighty Mouse, the problem, the only problem with Mighty Mouse is that he's in a weight class that's very small. There's not a lot of guys that weigh 125 pounds, so there's not the same talent pool that Anderson Silva dealt with. Anderson Silva dealt with much more danger in terms of one punch strikers. But the argument could be made that Anderson Silva when he was at the top is the greatest of all time. And then the argument could be made that Mighty Mouse is the greatest of all time. Mighty Mouse just destroyed people.

episode one of the games that was actually featured on the show we are gonna play here this is news to me same consequences as squid game all right colin roll the intro [Music] this show was at least the first time that i experienced a netflix show like this taking over the global conversation i mean i think it's the first time netflix has experienced it 100 so it's an extremely global show for a number of reasons the first being that it was released subtitled in 31 languages and dubbed in 13 on the exact same day netflix alone is available in 190 countries so it has the ability to reach a massive audience from day one the story itself had so much global appeal i think there's so much to be learned from how squid game was structured from a story perspective like this show and the narratives in it and the tropes in it just globally appealing it's a show about a bunch of people who are in debt in south korea and they get invited to a place to play a series of games where the winner at the end of all these games will win an amount of money that is so large that it would solve all their money problems and these are children's games they're going to play six games while they're there but if you lose a game you die so the stakes are incredibly high and it is done in a way that i think just captivated a global audience to a scale that we've never seen before to start it was extremely simple from the locations to the outfits everything was the most simple version i think what happens when you fix all of those elements and make them really simple the story gets easier to follow the players where this color the scary triangle men and square men and circlemen the soldiers where this color the front man wears this color like it was very clear-cut i think not only does the story get easier to follow but when everything is that simple when the games are that simple right the first game they play is red light green light green light red light everyone knows that game all over the world and if you don't know it you can understand it you run when it's green light you stop when it's red light so that ability to put yourself in the position of the character no matter where you are in the world that relatability keeps you more engaged at least i found that when i was watching i was like wait would i be able to stop quick enough to not get shot you know like you're thinking that in your head like how would i act in this game and i think that's a really important thing for anyone who's telling a story basically thinking about like how relatable is this could you even if this is a fantasy right even if this is a fictional world can you put yourself in the position of this character okay ready for game one sure colin and i each have ten marbles in our hands basically one of us is gonna put a certain amount in our hands and the other person has to guess if it's odd number of marbles or an even number and when you guess you wager a certain amount of marble so you could wager five marbles so if you guess it right you win five marbles from me your goal is to take as many marbles for me as possible we're gonna play this game three times during this recording okay now what you don't know is that by the end of the episode the person with the least number of marbles will have to eat something disgusting chosen by chris i'm chris it's my job to go to the store and find something horrible for the loser to eat odds are evens odd what do you have damn one thing i saw and i sent to everyone on our team was this meme where the front man was mr beast's voice i bought this entire island i brought in a bunch of my subscribers and gave them a chance to win tons of money i thought it was so funny and that's actually what pulled me into watching the show i was like this clearly relates to our world too and for someone to be able to draw such a parallel between what mr beast is doing and what's happening in this netflix show i thought that was really interesting the numbers that netflix released about their viewership like bridgerton had done 82 million views in the first 28 days it's interesting is like jimmy is competing on that level a lot of times like a lot of his episodes have 100 million views it's one of the most successful formats in all of entertainment you think about the price is right yeah the longest running show on television mr beast the number one channel right on youtube hunger games one of the most epic movie franchises money is a very universal stake that resonates all over the world in every different culture like we all are sort of beholden to the system that relies on money the two things that this show hinges on are money and death those two things are universally understandable we all when we're alive are playing by the rules of money and it's this game that we all understand like it is literally and figuratively hanging over our heads at all times yes and so that is so universally understandable like if you talk to anyone in any other country and you talk about making money you get it what else is it that makes this so appealing to watch and so engaging and what jimmy talks about a lot is retention and i think what squid game did really well was utilize some retention strategies that were just so good at building up tension in our bodies and then releasing that tension one tactic that squid game used very well was jenga storytelling so this is the idea that tension should rise over time and i think they did a really good job of building tension that continues to rise from episode one all the way until the finale there's more money up for grabs the further the series goes along and the more people that die so the stakes are rising and another tension point is pain the more time that goes on the more painful it will be for one of the players to lose right because they've already invested so much time and not only have they invested time but you're learning more about them like um i might butcher some of the yeah names here saibik she's like the main character she's one of the last three but you learned that she wants the money to save her little brother who's an orphan and needs like a family and you're like oh my god my stakes just increased gyoung is like this deadbeat you know character who's always just wanted validation and wants a connection to his mom and wants a connection to his daughter like as time goes on that state gets crazy high because you're like god i want this guy to have some money but what's interesting is that him winning money comes at the cost of someone losing their life or actually 400 some odd people losing their lives so it's a very complex emotion to feel the action of having to negotiate that in your mind as these stakes rise builds a lot of tension even when gyeong is playing marbles with the old man he's tricking him and you're not sure what you're supposed to feel it's a complex emotion of do i am i happy that he's gonna be okay and win because he's our main character or am i like really upset with him for tricking this guy like i think that increase of stakes as well as this release of tension that is emotionally like a roller coaster where sometimes you're happy sometimes you're sad sometimes you're confused that makes you so engaged in the show yeah you want to release tension at disproportionate levels because you want everyone on the edge of their seat totally unaware of what's going to happen next and a great way to do this is to introduce new narratives to the story and squid game did this really well you have a scenario where everyone shows up they think they're playing this game for money everyone here will participate in six different games over six days those who win all six games will receive a handsome cash prize they find out they're playing this game not only for money but also for their life [Applause] and we think okay the only way you die is if you play the game and you get out still terrible but those are the rules then we learn when someone gets murdered that that's another way to lose the game player 271 eliminated that was wild because that introduction of that rule creates tons of mayhem and again in the viewer's mind you're like whoa you figured that out along with the people in the show and that i think is really compelling they completely flip the switch and that's really powerful from a retention standpoint when it comes to storytelling mr beast does these narrative changes all the time where it's like okay you think that as long as you stay in this circle you win what you don't know is the circle's getting smaller and what you don't know is then you're gonna have to stand on one foot and then what you don't know is that you know and like all of a sudden it's like well you didn't know it you didn't know what you didn't know so what we're talking about here is keeping viewers on their toes by adding in new narratives let's say you're not a creator who's making a game show if you're a cooking channel how would you potentially work that into your story let's say you're doing a how-to what would be a secondary narrative try guys i think are a great example where like try guys cook without a recipe that's a great format to introduce unexpected things happening where like the audience knows the recipe or the audience knows how to make it they don't know they have to solve it they're going to throw in different ideas in the middle there's all the characters like creating a dynamic where narrative changes can happen just because the characters are in that flow i think works really well like just creating situations for viewers to be creating situations where there's room for what's not planned i think travel vlogs have so much room for the unplanned to make the videos great and also for even if you do have a show like you and i where like one of us doesn't know something or in this setting on this show both of us don't know something but the audience i think both of us don't know something you know has this all been orchestrated am i meant to lose is this what's happening [Music] [Laughter] this could be good oh that's good this might be it all right nerve-wracking let's play again again okay hold on i don't know what i did with my marbles colin's lost his marbles no i've got him even what is it is it odd that's a big wager oh man there's only one more game left oh that sucks i i really thought i was gonna get you on that oh six is tough yes all right so let's talk about how how does squid game impact the future of how creators are going to operate the future of what we're going to see on youtube specifically squid game pushed me to think about what is possible with creators i've never seen anything dominate a conversation globally in such a short amount of time like squid game and have such a ridiculous impact on all types of economies i saw jimmy fallon doing licking a honeycomb to get the umbrella out right it's like and that has a lot to do right with the fact that netflix is in 190 countries that they have the infrastructure to put out a show in 34 different languages all at once but if you look at what's happening on youtube channels are starting to dub over and subtitle their videos yep unilingo the company that does mr beast does get out of here we are totally in the minority and we're totally wrong and i went back and watched one of the episodes with the korean actors like their actual emotion yeah completely different there is a really good line from i think it's the creator of the show that said if viewers can get over the barrier of a one-inch subtitle text box the world of film will open up to them and i think that's really interesting that now we're starting to open up to more global content now we're starting to see it creep into you know the social media world with mr beast going into spanish all these other creators starting to explore dubbing but you really think about like the internet is a global place so it makes sense that the content would be globally accessible it's all about having the maximum potential audience setting yourself up for that level of success like there are certain topics that we could talk about on this show that we know don't have a huge audience buenos aires the other learnings that writers have been using for years and years and years that i think if you take the time to learn those things as a creator and study them you can apply them to your work yeah a great not from a production value perspective but from a storytelling perspective you have to compete you have to be telling a compelling story they are starting to follow similar business models though if pretty standard uh irish upbringing um i spent most of my life uh living in like this really rural part of ireland uh it was sort of surrounded by farms and fields and stuff yeah and i mean this was kind of problematic when so i remember we didn't get a computer for a long time and even we got a computer it took a long time before we got uh internet access and so i remember renting or borrowing books from the library that like read about the internet because we couldn't actually get the internet and so there's like a period of about two years when i was reading these amazing books about the like 0.5 k a second uh and so you know the workflow is like have a book with you while you use the internet because you go like read a page of your book you'd like look up see if the page is loaded only way to connect this like really rural part of ireland to the internet um and and that finally worked well and that was like 512k broadband but um the latency was horrible because like packets had fields.title: Why France produces the most World Cup players
fields.description: This is Portugal, playing Morocco at the 2018 World Cup.
fields.text: This is Portugal, playing Morocco at the 2018 World Cup. Portugal was the heavy favorite and won the game 1-0. The result wasn't all that interesting, but this photo is. This Portugal player wasn't born in Portugal, and these Morocco players weren't born in Morocco. See, soccer's regulating body, FIFA, allows athletes to play for any nation they have a clear connection to, including the country of players' parents or grandparents are from. In this year's World Cup, 82 players are playing for countries they weren't born in. So where are they coming from? If we plot it on a map, one country stands out. France is where the largest number of all World Cup players were born. Brazil has the next highest total, but it's not even close. France has had the most native players and coaches in the last four World Cups, and their dominance has been on the rise. So what's so special about France? At the end of World War II, much of France was destroyed. The government began recruiting laborers from southern and eastern Europe as well as colonies in northern Africa to rebuild the country during the late 1940s and 1950s. During that time, France brought in more immigrants than any other European country. And in the 1960s and early 70s, France's economy grew rapidly, and the labor shortage led to another wave of immigrants with even more arrivals from French colonies throughout Africa and the Caribbean. Many of them settled in major housing developments just outside of the major cities. At the same time, France was also in a sports crisis, especially the national football team. Between 1960 and 1974, France failed to qualify for three World Cups and three European Championships. The French football Federation decided the way to get better was to create a national structure for developing talent, so it established one of Europe's first football academy systems. In 1972, a national training center was open in Vichy. And four years later, the Federation worked with top French football clubs to set up a wider network of academies to recruit and train local youth. In 1988, the national training center moved to a forested suburb south of Paris called Clefante. And by the early 1990s, this French soccer system was one of the best in the world, developing talented players all over France. And the system delivered results. In 1998, the French national team called Leblou won the World Cup, a moment that was celebrated throughout the country. It seemed to be a breakthrough for French multiculturalism as well, since several players were either immigrants themselves or children of immigrants who came to France in the 20th century. The team was called Black Blunt Bitt, meaning Black White Arab, a spin on the three colors of the French flag. But not everyone supported diversity, particularly nationalist politicians like Jean-Marie Leppen. Despite racist criticism, players from immigrant families have continued to make up more and more of France's best talent. The French word literally means suburb, but it can also imply immigrant dominated get-ups. Over the years, these areas have frequently seen riots. They have high levels of unemployment, crime, and poverty in our in-acrisis. At the Vanlejo, continued to produce some of the most talented soccer players. That's because this is where France's immigration history meets its soccer system. And it's the reason why the city is the world's number one talent pool for soccer. Since 2002, the number of Parisian-born players of the World Cup has continued to rise. Out of all French players at the 2018 World Cup, 16 were born or raised in greater Paris. And the French national team has eight. That includes Killian Mbappe. France's 19-year-old superstar was born to an Algerian mother in Cameroonian father in the Parisian suburb of Bondi and was trained through the French system at Clefonten. But Parisian players don't just play for France. Over the years, FIFA's eligibility rules have allowed them to play for countries like the Ivory Coast, Morocco, Algeria, Portugal, Cameroon, and Toba. Four players on this year's Senegal team are from the greater Paris area, as well as this player on Tunisia. And remember this photo? Both of these players were born in Paris. That's what special about French soccer. The combination of an established academy system in its unique immigration history is producing incredible talent for France and the rest of the world.

fields.title: "Longevity Molecules" Preserve Hair & Hearing in Mice
fields.description: big news for mice and hopefully for people as the results of two new studies show that promising longevity interventions can regrow hair and combat hearing loss in mouse models first up scientists publishing in the journal pharmaceutics have successfully regrown hair in mice using dissolvable micro needles loaded with rapamycin and
fields.text: big news for mice and hopefully for people as the results of two new studies show that promising longevity interventions can regrow hair and combat hearing loss in mouse models first up scientists publishing in the journal pharmaceutics have successfully regrown hair in mice using dissolvable micro needles loaded with rapamycin and epigallocatechin gallate or egcg an active ingredient in green tea studies have found that rapamycin one of the most promising gero-protective drugs not only stimulates hair regrowth but can also partially reverse hair graying egcg is a polyphenol found in green tea and a potent antioxidant that has shown effectiveness against various conditions including androgenic alopecia combating hair loss is not just about looks understanding the mechanisms of senescent alopecia and ways to reverse it can provide insights into other aspects of aging in this new study the researchers used an emerging micro needle technology to deliver drugs directly to the inner layers of the skin cone like micro needles were loaded with nanoparticles containing rapamycin egcg or a combination the microneedles were applied to shaved parts of the mice's bodies and slowly dissolved releasing the drugs the researchers found the micro needle based treatment substantially more effective than topical application even though much higher doses were used topically rapamycin groups demonstrated more rapid hair growth while egcg groups had higher follicle density the best results were achieved with a combination of both the results were dose dependent with moderate doses of rapamycin being the most effective by day 15 of the experiment the mice on a rapamycin and egcg combination had their thick black fur restored almost completely while untreated controls hardly showed any hair growth at all the researchers also confirmed that the treatment resulted in increased autophagy in follicular regions and promoting autophagy is currently thought to be rapamycin's central mechanism of action this study reiterates the health potential of two molecules popular in the longevity field rapamycin and egcg additionally this microneedle-based drug delivery method could potentially be used to treat various other skin conditions in a separate study scientists have released a preprint showing that long-term supplementation of nicotinamide riboside or nr an nad precursor alleviates the progression of age-related hearing loss in mice globally age-related hearing loss is the most common sensory deficit of older people it is associated with several problems including cognitive decline social isolation and accident risk however the disease is often overlooked to determine the effects of long-term nr administration on hearing loss in mice the researchers administered nr through the drinking water of a treatment group with a control group receiving unaltered water both groups were then tested for hearing capability at the ages of 2 8 and 12 months it turned out that the supplementation prevented the progression of age-related hearing loss specifically at high sound frequencies besides the preventative benefits additional results suggest that nr even when administered in later life could benefit already affected mice at certain frequencies the hypothesis is that nr administration indirectly affects mitochondrial homeostasis and function thereby protecting cochlear cells from cytotoxic damage now these are mild studies more work is needed and there's no guarantee these results will translate to humans but what we're seeing here is strong additional support for molecules rapamycin egcg and an r that are already quite promising and are already used in humans but we'll keep you updated as we learn more so make sure to subscribe so you don't miss out i'm ryan o'shea and we'll see you next time on lifespan news [Music] [Music]

fields.title: The FTX Collapse, Explained | What Went Wrong | WSJ
fields.description: Over $150 billion.
fields.text: Over $150 billion. In three days, that's how much the world's 15 largest cryptocurrencies lost in market value. It's because of the crypto exchange platform FTX, which is behind this token, named FTT. On November 6, the tokens value began to fall, losing more than 80% of its worth in the span of 72 hours. Once seen as a survivor in a struggling market, the fall of FTX has sent shock waves through the cryptocurrency industry. So what went wrong? FTX is the brainchild of Sam Bankman Fried. He's commonly known as SPF on social media. He's been previously hailed as a savior of the crypto industry. You were called to JP Morgan on crypto. You had that father you or did not? It doesn't bother me too much. Bankman Fried founded the quantitative trading firm Alameda Research in 2017. Two years later, he started FTX, an exchange platform for buying or selling cryptocurrencies. Right now, he's the majority owner of both firms. That kind of aroused some skepticism among industry players and traders, investors, stakeholders that there could be some sort of conflict of interest in terms of whether Alameda Research was getting preferential treatment, FTX, vice versa. But the official narrative that SPF gave in the past is that the two companies are separate entities. After its launch, FTX attracted major investments from Silicon Valley and Wall Street. We've raised a few billion dollars over the course of the last couple of years and were profitable business. It grew into the fourth largest cryptocurrency exchange for derivatives trading. Celebrities promoted the platform and ads. I'm getting into crypto. With FTX, you're in? It's FTX. It's a safe and easy way to get into crypto. I don't think so. FTX was gaining steam and in the process often tussled with finance. The world's largest crypto exchange by volume. When FTX was getting started, finance invested in FTX and it was one of the crypto exchanges earliest investors. But FTX, as we know, grew really rapidly and became a very substantial rival to finance. As FTX grew in the industry, Bankman freed further his reputation as a crypto savior when digital asset prices collapsed earlier this year. He bailed out firms, bending about a billion dollars. But that image didn't last. On November 2nd, CoinDesk published a report based on a leaked Alameda balance sheet. According to the leaked data, Alameda claimed it had over $14 billion in assets at the end of June. But most of that was FTX's tokens. Alameda CEO Caroline Allison, we did that the balance sheet wasn't complete. Caroline also said, it's financial situation is under control. The company is doing well. However, it seems like the market just didn't really buy that and then traders continue to withdraw from FTX. FTX and Alameda did not respond to a request for comment. Things escalated on November 6th when finance said it would offload hundreds of millions of dollars of FTT. Finance did not respond to a request for comment. The announcement sparked mass withdrawals. That day FTX processed four billion dollars of transactions. Many times the normal amount for a day. Some got backlogged, which sparked demand for more. By November 7th, that number ballooned to $6 billion. On the 8th, a day later, FTX's finances were in crisis. Finance stepped in and said it would buy the company. It seemed like FTX might have solved its liquidity problem. But on the 9th, finance backed out of the non-binding acquisition. The next day, the journal reported that FTX used money from customers to fund risky bets made by Alameda. It's a shocking revelation for a lot of people in the industry, because even though there has been a lot of speculation about FTX and Alameda research being joined at the hip, nobody could have foreseen that SPF was willing to transfer billions of customer funds at the key's crypto exchange to help his crypto trading firm. The Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department are investigating FTX, according to a person familiar with the matter. This is not like the New York Stock Exchange or NASDAQ. They take people's money, they borrow against it, it's not much disclosure, and then they trade against their customers. A spokesperson for Justice Department declined to comment. Beckman freed told investors that FTX couldn't cover withdrawals, since its collateral was dropping in value and couldn't be liquidated, according to people familiar with the matter. On the 11th, Beckman freed resigned as CEO, and FTX and Alameda filed for bankruptcy. Afterwards FTX said it was probing a potential hack. More than $370 million worth of crypto funds appeared to be missing, according to crypto analytics firm Elliptic. On the 12th, the journal reported that Alameda and FTX executives knew that FTX had lent its customers money to Alameda. So a lot of retail traders and investors I've talked to are feeling desperate or frustrated the majority of the people in the industry could not have seen this coming because FTX is such a dominant player. The fallout has led other companies to tout their reserves and call for more transparency in the industry. As of November 11th, according to the bankruptcy filing, FTX's estimation of their liabilities would make it the largest crypto-related bankruptcy ever filed.

and now Western culture is really picking up on that especially in the last maybe half a century or so but green tea sort of leads that in being the healthiest right I mean we always hear green teas the best well taking it one step further we look at matcha and all matcha tea is is really just pulverized green tea but green tea gets its benefits from something that are called catechins and these catechins are what give you all the benefits I mean they're really what makes tea healthy so when you look at a polarized version of tea a pulverized version of these leaves it allows for greater absorption now there is a 2003 study by chromatography that found that when you actually pulverized green tea that it increased the catechins by 137 times that's like off-the-charts so the catechins are the good components of teas then obviously a pulverized version of them is going to be markedly better and we're gonna get a lot more the benefits out of those now the catechins of course as I said they're the components that give tea the benefits okay there's a lot of bio regulatory activities that tea helps that are just amazing like it's an antimicrobial its antioxidant it's an anti-inflammatory then it also helps lower blood pressure helps lower your cortisol levels it can lower your cholesterol and then additionally now it's being shown to help out your healthy gut flora so it helps increase the ratio of good gut flora to bad gut flora pretty darn remarkable now a lot of the positive benefits of green tea in general come from something called epic gallo catechin three gaily yes that is a huge mouthful but you've know it as EGCG okay remember all those infomercials always talking about EGCG it's like this amazing super miracle thing when all it is they're just trying to sell you some product that probably call a cost them like 30 cents to make EGCG is just the type of catechin that is most prevalent in green tea and helps mobilize fat now you can get a lot more out of that epic gala catechin three gay late if you just have a polarized version of green tea which we're talking about matcha here so in a 2011 study in Saito technology it was found that a Deb, that's a wrap. On behalf of British Airways, Comic Relief and Flying Start. Thank you for your attention and your kind donations. Every penny of which will help children all over the world. Living really tough lives. If you have any questions or you can't find your safety card. Or flying start envelope. Please ask one of your gorgeous cabin crew members. Have an enjoyable flight. Thank you.
